thread.title_full: VW scandal: 'Changes will not be painless' Volkswagen CEO tells staff as car maker prepares to slash spending

author: Justin Huggler in Berlin
title: VW scandal: 'Changes will not be painless' Volkswagen CEO tells staff as car maker prepares to slash spending
text:
VW scandal: 'Changes will not be painless' Volkswagen CEO tells staff as car maker prepares to slash spending Volkswagen boss Matthias Mueller says all planned investments will be placed under review Job cuts could loom at Volkswagen Photo: DPA By Justin Huggler in Berlin , and Julia Bradshaw in London 1:46PM BST 06 Oct 2015 Comments 
The chief executive of beleaguered car giant Volkswagen has warned staff that changes at the company will not be painless, signalling that job cuts might lie ahead as the German auto maker deals with the biggest crisis in its history . 
Matthias Mueller, who took over as CEO after former boss Martin Winterkorn was forced to resign in the wake of the diesel emissions-rigging scandal , told some 20,000 employees at the auto giant's headquarters in Wolfsburg that he would do everything to keep jobs secure but that the costs of dealing with the crisis would be high and that "every euro that stays in the company helps us". 
"We are re-examining all planned investments,” Mr Mueller said in his first address to workers. 
"Whatever is not absolutely necessary will be cut or postponed. I say this quite frankly: this will not be without pain. 
"Technical solutions to the problems are within view. However, the business and financial consequences are not yet clear." 
Mr Mueller also cautioned that care was more important than speed in clearing up the diesel emissions disaster. 
A VW Passat undergoes an emissions test 
But fixing some 11 million rigged vehicles will be expensive, and the €6.5bn VW has already set aside for repairs won't be enough to cover fines and potential legal damages as well, Mr Mueller said. 
The company is also exploring options from a simple software upgrade to replacing some cars outright, according to Bloomberg. 
The government of the German state of Lower Saxony, which owns a 20pc stake in VW, said it would do all it could to prevent job losses. 
"I am aware that work at Volkswagen is the livelihood for many thousands of workers and their families worldwide, and especially here in Lower Saxony," Stephan Weil, the state prime minister, wrote in a letter to staff. 
"That's why I see it as our task to work with all our strength for the safety of these jobs." 
The German government has given VW until tomorrow (Wednesday) to set out how it intends to fix the problem, which analysts say is likely to cost tens of billions of pounds to put right. 

The announcement followed news that eight million of the 11 million cars fitted with illegal emissions-cheating software were sold in Europe. 
A total 1.2 million of the affected cars are in the UK, including VWs, Audis, Seats, Skodas and VW vans. 
The admission came in a letter of apology to German MPs as VW mounts a huge PR campaign to try to undo some of the damage to its brand. 
The letter, sent to every MP with a VW outlet in his or her constituency, apologises for the "wrongdoing of a few individuals" and promises to "carry out a full investigation of what happened with the help of German and American lawyers". 
"Rest assured that we are currently working at full speed and in close co-operation with the authorities... on a technical solution for the vehicles concerned," it says. 
The company used column inches on Sunday, as Germany was celebrating 25 years of reunification, to reassure Germans that it would resolve the crisis. 
"Actually, our reunification anniversary message should be here,” the advertisement read. 
"It would have been the right moment to say thank you for our customers’ confidence in our cars and for the great popularity VW has experienced during this time in Germany. 
"But now we only have one sentence to say to you. We will do everything to regain your trust." 
The scandal has wiped almost €30bn off the value of VW and prompted a raft of government investigations and lawsuits around the world.
